snippet: President Obama called the fight against Ebola “a top national security priority,” but did not specify how screening procedures would be changed.
abstract: Pres Obama says screening for Ebola virus at airports both in the United States and West Africa will increase, but does not offer specifics; Dallas residents remain on edge as they await to learn if those who came into contact with Ebola patient Thomas Eric Duncan became infected.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Mark Landler from Washington; Andrew Pollack from Los Angeles; David Montgomery from Austin, Tex.; and Timothy Williams from New York.

lead_paragraph: President Obama called the fight against Ebola “a top national security priority,” but did not specify how screening procedures would be changed.

headline.main: Ebola Screening at Airports Will Increase, Obama Says
headline.print_headline: Ebola Screening at Airports Will Increase, Obama Says

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
